Posts.Content: mlrbelle wrote: I'm currently awaiting biopsy results, but surgeon agrees with Birads 5 rating on mammo results and believes it is cancer.  The lab results and surgeon both have indicated MRI is the next step to ascertain the extent of the disease and to double-check the other side.  However, I spoke with a friend who had a bilateral masectomy a few years ago, and she recommended thermography and PET scan.  What exactly is the difference between an MRI and a PET scan?  Also, has anyone had thermogram done? Any advice would be greatly appreciated. Dx 10/12/2009, DCIS, 6cm+, Stage 0, Grade 3, 0/2 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: MRI/PET scans; Thermography?? mlrbelle rickfigley

Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2010 09:10AM mlrbelle wrote: They actually don't look as bad to others as they do to us - at least that's what all my friends told me LOL!  You can also PM timtam on BCO to request access to the photo gallery.  There are photos of all phases/types of reconstruction.  This helped me a lot in getting an idea what "normal" was supposed to be and what the end result would be.

Posts.Title: Normal procedure for biopsy results? mlrbelle unklezwifeonty

Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2009 05:10PM mlrbelle wrote: So sorry to hear that you had a microinvasion!  I did as well, but mine was microscopic and the margins were clear and wide so I will not have any further treatment. However, my doctors did anticipate an invasive component prior to my surgery.  My PS said that it was fine to have the TEs placed before chemo but he would probably wait to do the fills until after my chemo was finished and my body had recovered.  His only concern was radiation, which they thought I would need also and was why I had to delay my reconstruction altogether (hoping now for January/February).  Even with rads though, some PS are fine with the TEs in place during treatment.  You might have a little longer reconstruction, but it should not affect it otherwise from what I've read. Good luck and try to put all this aside for at least a few days and enjoy your b-day and Christmas!
Posts.Title: Dx'd with DCIS /mastectomy, now have microinvasion Just-Sher momto3

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2009 06:42PM mlrbelle wrote: Well, I'm back.  The surgeon is in agreement with the mammo report.  He did a needle biopsy on the lump, and I have an appointment to go back for the results on Monday afternoon.  I can't believe it takes that long (they have to send it out due to my insurance)!!  If it comes back malignant as is the preliminary diagnosis, we will move to an MRI for both breasts and start planning mastectomy as the mass itself is huge (6cm x 2.5 cm), covering 1/2 my left side. I just can't believe this is happening - I'm only 35!
Posts.Title: Surgeon appt this afternoon - questions? mlrbelle sheila1951

Posts.Content: May 7, 2010 01:01PM mlrbelle wrote: You are not a freak!  You will probably swing back and forth from where you are now to scared to about a million other emotions throughout your treatment and beyond.  Even if you don't, it's perfectly normal - all bets are off.  Me?  I got scared, depressed, then determined, then pissed and back and forth, and still do circle around from time to time.  And I've only been in this since October '09.
Posts.Title: ???? ashleychalmers caaclark

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2009 12:12PM mlrbelle wrote: I would call your primary/family dr.  I am stage 0 and had bilateral mastectomy with no other treatment, and my PCP is following me in 3 months, then 6 months, then every year (minus symptoms of course).  I won't have mammograms since I have no "breasts", but she will be doing extra bloodwork at a minimum.  I will also get ultrasounds from my ob/gyn.  FWIW - I am ER/PR- and HER+++. She told me something that alot of others seem to refute and ignore - anyone who has had cancer (of any type) is at a greater risk of developing a second cancer (of any type).  It's just the way it is, and they don't know why.  So, I would find someone who will be willing to follow you at least minimally. BTW - my mom had lumpectomy and rads, followed by Tamoxifen and is still followed 6+ years later.
Posts.Title: Follow up for Stage I's carcharm 1Lizzy
